Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A New Class of High-conductivity Solid-state Composite Electrolytes for Next-generation Lithium Batteries
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to enable high-performance, safe, lithium-based batteries; a $40B market today and growing rapidly driven by the needs of electric vehicles and grid-based storage. This project will develop a safe (non-flammable) electrolyte that can operate at both high voltages (for increased battery capacity) and high temperature (for rapid charging). The proposed electrolyte is a drop-in replacement in todayâ€™s manufacturing infrastructure. Key experiments will allow the team to develop a fundamental understanding of the materials properties and allow it to circumvent crucial performance limiters. As an enabler for an all solid-state battery, the innovation will improve performance of electric vehicle batteries at reduced costs, accelerating the rate of penetration of US-made electric vehicles and power trains in world markets.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop, test, scale-up, and begin commercialization of a next-generation solid-state composite electrolyte for inherently safe, high-performance lithium-/lithium-ion batteries. The electrolyte should have high electrochemical stability, high ionic conductivity, high thermal stability, a high lithium transference number, low interfacial resistance, and will be inherently non-flammable. Full cells >200 mAh will be constructed and performance tested. During the Phase I effort, NextGen will demonstrate that its new electrolyte will meet the conductivity, temperature, safety, etc. goals for advanced electrolytes required by early market adopters. The project has four key tasks: (1) ceramic materials synthesis and characterization, (2) blending with a polymer to form a thin, pinhole-free composite solid-state electrolyte system to achieve simultaneously a high ionic conductivity and a low resistance interface with the cathode/anode materials, (3) electrochemical and thermal characterization of the composite electrolyte system, and (4) assembly and test of full cells to demonstrate that the electrolyte meets the system performance requirements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

NextGen's Phase I effort has advanced the state-of-the-art by demonstrating that its newly developed, non-flammable solid electrolyte can be incorporated in lithium-ion cells and that it has the potential to address the unmet needs of batteries used in medical devices and unmanned aerial vehicles. Success in the Phase I feasibility effort enabled NextGen to identify and engage with leading battery and original equipment manufacturers to be its industry partners in the Phase II development program. These companies are potential future customers as well. The goal of NextGen's Phase II program is to optimize the solid electrolyte formulation and cell architecture with respect to battery chemistries of interest to its industrial collaborators, so as to be able to meet the target performance requirements of specific applications. This in turn will allow the solid electrolyte enabled cells to be qualified for commercial use.

Intellectual Merit

NextGen's successful Phase I effort addressed the two critical aspects of lithium-ion batteries, namely Safety and Reliability. Organic electrolytes used in conventional lithium-ion batteries are flammable, and pose the risk of catastrophic fire or explosion. NextGen's newly developed, non-flammable solid electrolyte with a unique heterostructure, has (i) high lithium-ion conductivity at room temperature, and (ii) desirable interfacial properties that result in low-resistance electrode-electrolyte interfaces, while effectively blocking lithium dendrites that are a primary cause for battery related hazards. NextGen's solid electrolyte has been successfully tested in prototype cells using commercial cathodes and a lithium metal anode, and presents a unique opportunity to significantly enhance the current energy density without compromising safety. The solid electrolyte is produced via a scalable process that can be integrated with roll-to-roll battery manufacturing lines. The two key objectives of NextGen's Phase II program are: (i) identify and optimize chemistry-specific cell design to meet the target energy density and performance criteria for specific applications, and (ii) demonstrate scaled-up manufacturability of the solid electrolyte. To accomplish these objectives, NextGen will adopt a practical approach that exploits synergy between materials, processing and characterization, with a focus on demonstrating cell-level performance criteria specified by its partners. By the end of Phase II program NextGen will have optimized its solid electrolyte material, charted a path to large volume manufacturing, and embarked on commercialization for the targeted applications.

Broader Impact

A non-flammable, easy-to-manufacture solid electrolyte that is also compatible with lithium metal, would not only ensure unparalleled safety along with a significant improvement in the energy density, but would also dramatically alter the economics of lithium-ion batteries by eliminating extrinsic costs associated with thermal management and explosion containment, both during manufacture and use. NextGen's Phase II development program is specifically designed to establish manufacturing infrastructure in the United States, since its near-term customers are all US-centric. This would not only create well-paying manufacturing jobs, but would also assist expanding the lithium battery ecosystem in the United States. Furthermore, the collaborations that NextGen developed with universities and National Laboratories during the course of Phase I effort will be expanded in the Phase II program to address the scientific challenges using an interdisciplinary approach. NextGen will disseminate this knowledge through research papers and seminars to inspire students and young researchers.
